moves.1. d4 f5 2. Bf4 Nf6 3. Nf3 e6 4. h4: Let's question the Dutch at once.
moves.4... Be7 5. h5: Why not? The pawn is safe, g6 is bad for black.
moves.5... h6: Stopping the pawn, but letting a wide hole on g6.
moves.6. Ne5: So, with six "unnatural" moves, I have a grimp on black.
moves.6... Nd5: I calculated here that I could lose the bishop for developing the queen.
moves.10. Qg5+ Kh7 11. h6: Threatening, but fearing the attack will lose steam. What can I save from it?
moves.11... Qg8 12. Qxg8+ Kxg8 13. h7+ Kh8: Well, a "hard to attack" pawn on h7... not bad. Oh, a pawn less, of course.
moves.14. g4: The only way I saw to "do something" but leave him develop. If d6, g4.
moves.14... fxg4 15. c4: I don't want to give him tempo, but I finally will have to.
moves.15... Nb4 16. Na3: Well, I developed the knight on a bad square, but I have a freeway to castling.
moves.16... d6 17. Nxg4 Rf4: I didn't foresee before d4 will fall.
moves.18. Ne3 Rxd4: Now, a knight on c2 is mate. But I have another threat.
moves.19. Nb5: Deadly. But black can try something... Bd8.
moves.19... Bd7 20. Nxc7: Cashing the wrong rook! In fact, it is very dangerous to leave this central black dominance.
moves.20... Nb8c6 21. Nxa8 Ne5: It's incredible black hasn't found a way to mate me.
moves.22. a3 Nbc6 23. b3 Na5 24. Rb1: Paying the price of taking the wrong rook. Now black has all his pieces active...
moves.26. Nc2 Be4 27. Nxd4: Finally removing the annoying central rook.
moves.27... Bxb1 28. Rxe6 Kxh7 29. Rxd6 Nac6 3: Contolling the bishops and freeing mine before getting greedy.
No pawns, no hope for black.
moves.35... Bb4+ 36. Kf1 Bd3+ 37. Kg1: Shielded the king, there is no plan for black.
